Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Social Organizing and Social Media

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
For many, social media are valuable because they allow a wider variety of voices to be heard and more varied accounts of events to become part of the public record. For social scientists interested in how social media are affecting our society, these claims raise a number of important questions. How does the social media record differ from a traditional archive? How do the "selves" that people produce digitally compare to those they inhabit in ordinary interpersonal contexts? The research supported by this award, which trains an American graduate student in methods of conducting empirically-grounded scientific research, will address these questions. The research is important because we need to understand all aspects of how social media affect our society and our institutions.

The research will be carried out by Rice University anthropology doctoral student, Baird Campbell, with the guidance of Dr. A. Cymene Howe. The researcher has chosen Santiago, Chile, as his research site. This is an appropriate site because Chile went through a marked political transition in the late 1990s. This created a unique boundary and clear contrast between past and present, and led to the rise numerous groups trying to re-write history and change their own public images through social media. The researcher will take advantage of this contrast and activism to compare traditional and official written accounts with contemporary digital archives. He also will conduct participant observation in activist groups; interview a stratified sample of group members, comparing their in-person narratives with their digital ones; conduct focus groups, stratified by age, to account for generation differences; and collect data thorough an on-line survey. Findings from this research will contribute to social science theories of the relationship between social media, social memory, and history. It will also help policy makers who must regularly evaluate the role of social media in the society at large.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the help of the NSF-DRIG, I was able to carry out 6 months of ethnographic fieldwork with trans activists in Santiago, Chile, focusing specifically on their usage of social media, both personally and for the purposes of the activism. Given the particular history of dictatorship and forced disappearance of Chile, the establishment of a coherent historical narrative is crucial for marginalized social groups who wish to be seen as politically viable. My fieldwork shows that social media is one of the main spaces in which this collective memory and history are negotiated, disputed, and formed. The mechanism for this process can be partially understood through the concept of the "archive of the self," I term I theorize in my forthcoming doctoral dissertation. Put simply, given that trans people have largely been excluded from the Chilean historical record, social media represents a unique space in which they can narrate and preserve their own histories without the traditional barriers for entry that state archives often present for marginalized people. The concept of the archive of the self proposes that social media be viewed as both a new archival technology and a technology for the formation and negotiation of the self. My field research shows that social media constitutes a proving ground for new facets of individual identity, where they can be tried on, tested, and reacted to in the larger environment of a given social media platform. This feedback in turn changes the nature of this nascent selfhood in accordance with existing and nascent societal paradigms, which influence the subsequent content to be published. In this way, the social media archive and the self can be seen as mutually constitutive, existing in a dialectical relationship. While this process is perhaps easier to see in the context of trans activism—as the process of self-making is more intentional and overt—I assert that this concept is useful for understanding selfhood in the digital age, coinciding with one of the stated broader impacts of my original proposed research. The study also has potentially useful implications for trans activists, as well as members of other marginalized groups, who wish to better understand the relationship between social media—ubiquitous in most modern activism—and marginalized subjectivities.
